pros: An amazing team of likeminded people with 1 goal - to ensure all of its students & residents gain the independence and care that they deserve 👏 ❤
cons: can be highly challenging but also extremely rewarding

review_title: Left with chronic stress. Very poor departmental management.
job_title: Digital Communications Officer in Cheltenham, England
pros: Beautiful surroundings, meaningful work, varied work. The brand achieved very good growth in the sector. High level of expertise within care and therapy. Free gym, swimming, sports facilities. Free car parking and bus service.
cons: Poor pay for industry. Lack of understanding of job roles outwith care, therapy and education. Zero job specific professional development unless you work in care or education. Over worked, set up to fail, lack of appropriate support. Quite political in terms of appointments, promotions and interdepartmental arbitration. Zero departmental vision.

pros: Great place to work. Would recommend
cons: Limited access to the main site Ullenwood

pros:
Staff are wonderful (depending on the unit), you will get to spend plenty of time with the students who are some of the most optimistic and resilient people I have ever met. 
Some of the Management actually seem to care, my current manager is amazing and is probably the best I'll ever work with. I also have the privilege of working with the best team on the campus. These people are some of the kindest and most compassionate individuals I will ever work with. The only thing keeping them at NSC is each-other and their students who they love unconditionally. To most of us it's more than just a job, which is why what I am about to write next will be quite painful for me to admit.
cons:
NSC will treat you better than most employees, but it does have a darker side which will rear its ugly head if the staff make to much noise on a particular issue. 
For example, like most care employers they label violent behaviour and sexual assault of staff as "challenging behaviour". This also includes being smeared with feces and vaginal secretions. 

 If staff do not wish to be exposed to this behaviour they are told they are free to leave. The standard response is thus: 'this is challenging behaviour, this is what we do. I you do not like it you are free to leave'. That is a direct quote which from one of the senior managers which is often parroted by their subordinates. 

Also be aware that you will have to pay for any courses you take when you leave and the current notice period has been extended to 60 days for new staff.

pros: Rewarding, no day is the same, plenty of opportunity.
cons: Cannot think of anything to add here.

pros:
Nice people to work for
Colleagues are helpful and there is generally very welcoming culture
cons:
Company is a little ossified and behind the times. 
If you are looking to aggressively advance this is not the place for you.

pros: good employee benefits, many opportunities to learn and progress, wonderful students and colleagues.
cons: Working constantly understaffed, at times work can be emotionally challenging

pros: Great Family ethos but they dont listen to staff.
cons: Acute staff shortage High rate of staff turnover

pros: Life changing work for both service users and employees
cons: Big place, impossible to know everyone

pros:
Fab Team
Good quality training
Good holidays as term time
cons:
Poor pay
Expects way too much for the pay

pros: Good continues training, friendly staff
cons: Expected a lot from staff, low pay

pros:
Firstly a wonderful charity and has transformed so many lives, inspirational and offer so many services to people with disabilities..
Beautiful ullenwood campus environment. 
Use of pool / gym.
On site catering services.
Expanding and growing company. 
Majority of staff are friendly, supportive and caring.
Career development opportunities if your face fits. 
Excellent induction training preparing you for the role. 
Staff feedback usually actioned.
Always overtime available due to shortage of staff. 
Pay is better than most healthcare settings, however with todays cost of living not great, many people have to work overtime hours to boost pay.
cons:
Physically and mentally draining, increasingly complex service users / high medical care and challenging behavior. 
No breaks, even on 12 hour shifts. Breaks are paid so due to the busy environment you are expected to continue working throughout. 
Rarely see the senior management team mix unless inspections are taking place.
Low pay for very high responsibility and stress. 
Some individuals in other departments look down upon care staff, lack of respect is evident.
Refresher training not planned and given when it should be. 
Currently a very high rate of care staff turnover resulting in continuous and constant recruitment drives, lowered standards and a high use of unfamiliar external agency staff many of who's level of care commitment is questionable. 
Required equipment to carry out job role is not always readily accessable such as laptops / computers, recording stations. 
No staff rooms in residences / no time away from the work floor. 
Recent years appear to be employing many people who are unqualified, unskilled and generally lack any sense of a caring nature. 
If your face fits and you do exactly as you are told you will be left alone and may be able to progress into senior management roles, if you question anything or speak up you will eventually be constructivley dismissed or out the door.
Terrible sickness policy, front line care staff sit within the same policy as office based staff. 
Early / Late shifts. Finishing at 11pm and back in at 7am. Little sleep / fatigue, no social life, long hours on alternate weekends. 
Senior management team are rarely seen  mixing "on the floor" or checking in on service users or co-workers, until there is an inspection or visitors then they are tripping over eachother to support!

pros: It's a great place to be, with very good training and lots of opportunity to get involved with new things. Everyone who works here works hard, and I like being surrounded by people who take their job seriously - and because we're all working towards the same goals, it's a really pleasant place to be. It's a tough job, but a very rewarding one.
cons: Nothing really. You have to drive to get to main campus and on some days parking isn't great, but there's overflow parking.

pros: A very positive place to work.  The culture of the organisation means that people care about each other.  Lots of opportunities for personal development and training.
cons: The college is not on a bus route so the location makes it difficult to travel to if you don't drive.

pros:
I worked for agencies for quite a few years before joining National Star College, after seeing what was out there over the previous 17 years it is easy to say National Star is was the only Organisation I was willing to accept on a permanent contract with.
Friendly, professional, good management, excellent colleagues and wonderful students.
cons: Like all care work the pays not great, £10.50ph for nights

pros: Provides great job satisfaction seeing the difference the organisation makes to people with disabilities; good culture that values staff and promotes development and offers good opportunities for promotion or moves into different roles
cons: It is hardwork - but you get the training to help you and you are rewarded as you really do make a difference

pros: Lovely environment, A very friendly team, Great ideas in moving forward to better care and learning for our students, A very rewarding feeling at the end of a shift,
cons: I can not think of any.

pros: Great opportunities for students , rewarding for staff
cons: You are committed and balance is difficult if your not a robot.

pros: Good people to work with. Never boring at work, it's always something to do. Busy as everywhere in care. And also plenty of holidays for term time only staff.
cons: Not everyone can work with learning disabilities. Mentally hard job.

pros: Understanding Employer, Caring management and stunning views
cons: Commuting from Gloucester not great as require drive to top of the hill in massive traffic.

pros: Great staff, management are good and always pleasant, good job benefits, interesting and satisfying job.
cons: None

pros: People - staff, students and residents
cons: Can’t think of any really

pros: None at all dreadful place to work
cons:
Micro managed
Blame culture
Massive turn over of staff
Bullying
